This whole collection is a mindblowing privilege to be exploring. To the folks responsible for digitizing and publicizing it: nice work.

comment._content: Glad you’re enjoying them.  The Library is pleased to be able to share the photographs with new audiences!

comment._content: Amazing photo indeed, but I cannot find the "train in the background" I even went to persistent URL, and still couldn't find it. If anyone can find it please add note so I can see it.

comment.author: 58545637@N00
comment._content: Great photos, both those of Feiniger and the entire collection you made available. And it's always a pleausre to revisit good old kodachromes and theirs incomparable intense and profound colors. Congratulations Library of the congress!

comment.author: 23065916@N04
comment._content: Just so I'm clear, are these bridges a series of loops for a train to climb out of the canyon?

comment.author: 35321343@N06
comment._content:
I've never seen image that looks like illustration..this is perfect composition..
Thank you for showing ...

comment.author: 62698460@N03
comment._content: The bridges are connecting rock crushing facilities on one side of the canyon with the mill and ore transfer facilities on the other. The open pit is out of sight at the rear of the picture. The buildings on the floor of the canyon are probably the outskirts of the one-street town of Bingham Canyon. The tracks don't get any closer to the floor than what is seen here.
